text:
On the other hand, it's ei375:turning out to be another very bad financial week for Asia. The financial ei377:assistance from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are not ei378:helping. In the last twenty four hours, the value of the Indonesian stock market has ei379:fallen by twelve percent. The Indonesian currency has ei380:lost twenty six percent of its value. In Singapore, stocks ei381:hit a five year low. In the Philippines, a four year low. And in Hong Kong, a three percent ei382:drop. More problems in Hong Kong for a place, for an economy, that many experts ei384:thought was once ei438:invincible. Here's ABC's Jim Laurie.
Not that long ago, before the Chinese ei386:takeover, the news about real estate here was that the sky was the limit the highest prices in the world. So when Wong Kwan ei388:spent seventy million dollars for this house, he ei389:thought it was a great ei390:deal. He ei391:sold the property to five buyers and ei392:said he'd ei393:double his money.
In Hong Kong, is always belongs to the seller's market.
Now with new ei395:construction under way, three of his buyers have ei397:backed out. And Wong Kwan will be lucky to ei398:break even. All across Hong Kong, the property market has ei399:crashed. Pamela Pak ei400:owns eight condominiums here. Pak can't ei401:find buyers. She ei402:estimates her properties, ei403:worth a hundred thirty million dollars in October, are ei404:worth only half that now.
They ei405:believe ah it will be always up ei406:going up and up ah forever. Nobody ei407:believe this any more.
Of all of Asia's economies, Hong Kong is the most robust. But in the past three months, stocks have ei408:plunged, interest rates have ei409:soared and the ei410:downturn all across Asia means that people are not ei412:spending here.
Hotels are only thirty percent full. You can ei414:get seventy percent ei415:discounts at the shopping malls. Three thousand dollar pearls for eight hundred dollars. A two hundred dollar wool jacket for fifty dollars. Still, there are few buyers. And at the big brokerage houses, after ten years of ei417:boom, they're ei418:talking about ei419:layoffs.
I ei420:think that the mood is fairly ei436:gloomy, and I ei422:think it's not going to ei424:change for a couple of years.
So for Hong Kong, it's time, as investment bankers like to say, to ei426:reposition. To either ei427:hold on tight or ei428:get out, as much of Asia ei429:goes into ei430:recession. Jim Laurie, ABC News, Hong Kong.

For his part, Fidel Castro is the ultimate political survivor. People have ei415:predicted his ei416:demise so many times, and the US has ei417:tried to ei418:hasten it on several occasions. Time and again, he ei419:endures. He has ei420:outlasted and sometimes ei421:outsmarted eight American presidents. Fidel Castro ei422:invited John Paul to ei423:come for a reason. Those observers ei449:looking for a ei450:battle between uncompromising representatives and very different ideologies will, in all likelihood, be ei451:disappointed.

The main negative is the risk that the Pope's ei458:visit will ei459:persuade a great many more Cubans to ei460:break loose of the Cuban government. If so, then the Pope's ei461:visit would really ei462:open up a new chapter in the government's relations with its own society. For the Cuban government, that is the risk.

After a two-hour ei1542:meeting at his Kennebunkport home with King Hussein of Jordan, Bush ei1543:said, ``I did not ei1544:come away with any feeling of hope'' that Iraq would ei1546:withdraw its army from Kuwait. Bush also ei1547:said Thursday that King Hussein ei1548:assured him Jordan would ei1549:close the last remaining free port to most Iraqi trade as the economic ei1550:embargo on materials to Iraq ei1551:continued unabated. Foodstuffs are among the goods being ei1553:blocked from entry; Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. Pentagon sources in Washington meanwhile ei1555:said the Bush administration ei1556:plans to ei1557:deploy 45,000 Marines to the region to ei1558:back up the thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force troops already in place in the gulf and the Saudi desert. At a news ei1560:conference, Secretary of State James A. Baker III ei1561:said Jordan `` is ei1562:seeking some guidance'' about a provision in the U.N.-backed trade embargo that ei1566:allows food for humanitarian purposes. Worries however ei1567:grew about the safety of Americans and other Westerners ei1569:trapped in Kuwait. Iraqi military authorities ei1570:ordered all Americans and Britons in Kuwait to ei1571:assemble at a hotel, officials ei1572:said. ``Very few'' of the 2,500 Americans in occupied Kuwait ei1573:complied with the order, a senior U.S. official ei1574:told The Associated Press. Iraq ei1575:said the ei1576:roundup was to ei1577:protect them from unspecified ei1578:threats; British Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave ei1579:called the order ``grave and sinister.'' ``What we ei1581:fear is that they will be ei1582:interned somewhere, most likely in Iraq,'' Waldegrave ei1583:said. A total of about 3,000 Americans, 3,000 Britons and more than 450 Japanese are in Iraq and Kuwait. Overall, more than 2 million foreigners are in both countries. Iraq has called them ``restrictees.'' In addition to the estimated 45,000 Marines to ultimately be part of Operation Desert Shield, Stealth fighter planes and the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy are also ei1586:headed to Saudi Arabia to ei1587:protect it from Iraqi expansionism. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams ei1589:said Iraq has ei1590:continued to ei1591:increase its armed forces in Kuwait and they now number about 160,000. Saddam has been under international quarantine since his Aug. 2 ei1594:power-grab, or what he ei1595:calls an ``eternal ei1742:merger'' with Kuwait. In a long verbal ei1597:attack read on Iraqi television Thursday, Saddam repeatedly ei1598:called Bush ``a liar'' and ei1600:said a shooting ei1601:war could ei1602:produce body bags courtesy of Baghdad. ``We ei1603:continue to ei1604:pray and ei1605:pray hard to God so that there will be no ei1606:confrontation whereby you will ei1607:receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins after you had ei1609:pushed them into a dark tunnel,'' Saddam ei1610:said. text: O'SMACH, Cambodia (AP)_ The top commander of a Cambodian resistance force ei2455:said Thursday he has ei2456:sent a team to ei2457:recover the remains of a British mine removal expert ei2458:kidnapped and ei2459:presumed ei2460:killed by Khmer Rouge guerrillas almost two years ago. Gen. Nhek Bunchhay, a loyalist of ousted Cambodian Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh, ei2461:said in an ei2462:interview with The Associated Press at his hilltop headquarters that he ei2463:hopes to ei2464:recover the remains of Christopher Howes within the next two weeks. Howes had been ei2465:working for the Britain-based Mines Advisory Group when he was ei2466:abducted with his Cambodian interpreter Houn Hourth in March 1996. There were many conflicting accounts of his ei2468:fate. Howes' team was ei2469:clearing mines 17 kilometers (10 miles) from Angkor Wat, the fabled 11th century temple that is Cambodia's main tourist attraction, when it was ei2470:attacked. In January this year, British police officers who had been ei2471:searching for Howes ei2472:concluded he had probably been ei2473:killed soon after being ei2474:captured. The Foreign Office ei2475:said it had ei2476:informed the family of Howes, 37 years old when he was ei2477:kidnapped, that he probably ei2478:died within weeks or months of his ei2479:capture on March 26, 1996. ``Obviously, it is deeply ei2480:discouraging for the family after 22 months, but there is no proof of life. But there is no evidence in either direction _ that there is proof of life or death,'' ei2487:said a Foreign Office spokesman, ei2488:speaking with customary anonymity. ``We will ei2489:continue to ei2490:do everything we can to ei2491:establish what has ei2492:happened.'' Thai military officials who monitor Cambodian affairs ei2493:said privately Thursday that Britain, through its embassies in Thailand and Cambodia, has been ei2494:pushing hard to ei2495:resolve the Howes case as the second ei2543:anniversary of his ei2497:abduction nears. Nhek Bunchhay, who had been closely ei2498:involved in the ei2499:search for Howes before having to ei2500:flee the Cambodian capital after a ei2501:coup d'etat last year, ei2502:appeared confident he would ei2503:find Howes' remains. He ei2504:said he ei2505:received information from Khmer Rouge guerrillas on where the body had been ei2506:buried, and recently ei2507:ordered 10 of his men from a force of 500 near Khmer Rouge headquarters in Anlong Veng to ei2508:conduct the ei2509:search. If and when the remains are ei2510:found, he ei2511:said, they would be ei2512:turned over to the British Embassy, apparently meaning they would be ei2513:sent across the border into Thailand and onward to Bangkok. Nhek Bunchhay ei2514:said he now ei2515:believed Howes had been ei2516:killed within a week of his ei2517:capture by a Khmer Rouge faction loyal to Pol Pot, then the guerrilla group's leader. Pol Pot is ei2518:considered ei2519:responsible for the radical ei2520:policies that ei2521:led to the ei2522:deaths of as many as 1.7 million Cambodians when the communist group ei2523:held power in the late 1970s. At the time Howes was ei2524:captured, the Khmer Rouge were a more or less united guerrilla force with more than 10,000 men under arms. But the group ei2525:began to ei2526:fall apart in mid-1996 after the ei2527:defection of one of its top leaders, Ieng Sary. Other commanders, and thousands of guerrillas, ei2528:followed him. A small hardcore group under Pol Pot ei2529:continued to ei2530:hold out at their headquarters at Anlong Veng in northern Cambodia near the Thai border. But in June last year, the remaining leadership had a ei2531:falling out, and Pol Pot was ei2532:arrested. In July last year in Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital, Second Prime Minister Hun Sen ei2533:staged a successful ei2544:coup d'etat against First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh. Ranariddh's loyalists, including Nhek Bunchhay, his top military commander, ei2535:went into hiding or ei2536:fled the capital. Nhek Bunchhay, ei2537:evading an intensive ei2538:manhunt, ei2539:made his way to O'Smach, the last major outpost held by Ranariddh's forces. His men have held the stronghold _ which is on the border just opposite the Thai province of Surin _ against repeated intense ei2540:attacks by Hun Sen's troops. They have been ei2541:aided by Khmer Rouge guerrillas from Anlong Veng, who have ei2542:formed an alliance with Ranariddh's resistance forces to oppose Hun Sen.

The ei2063:assassination ei2064:touched off a murderous ei2065:rampage by Hutu security forces and civilians, who ei2066:slaughtered mainly Tutsis but also Hutus who ei2067:favored ei2068:reconciliation with the minority. It also ei2069:reignited the civil ei2070:war. The panel also will ei2071:look at the ei2072:exodus of about 2 million Rwanda Hutus to neighboring countries where they ei2073:lived in U.N.-run refugee camps for 2 1/2 years. The ei2074:investigation will ei2075:consider the role of ``internal and external forces prior to the ei2077:genocide and subsequently, and the role of the United Nations and its agencies and the OAU before, during and after the ei2079:genocide,'' the OAU ei2080:said. text: MOSCOW (AP)_ Presidents Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine and Boris Yeltsin of Russia ei2306:signed an economic cooperation plan Friday, and Yeltsin ei2307:claimed they ei2308:resolved even more nagging problems. Russia and Ukraine share similar cultures and languages, and Ukraine was ei2309:ruled from Moscow for centuries. But while the two Slavic neighbors see themselves as natural partners, their relations since the ei2310:breakup of the Soviet Union have been ei2311:bedeviled by a number of ei2312:disputes _ Black Sea naval bases, border problems and Ukraine's natural gas debts. ``We have ei2313:covered the entire list of questions and ei2314:discussed how we will be ei2315:tackling them,'' Yeltsin was ei2316:quoted as ei2317:saying by the ITAR-Tass news agency. ``I must ei2318:say there are no unsettled problems any more. We have ei2319:solved them all.'' But his sweeping statement contained no details, and gave no indication of how the ei2320:disputes could be ei2321:resolved. Their solution would ei2322:require a ei2323:compromise between the two nations' parliaments. A major ei2324:dispute concerns a broad political treaty calling for border demarcation, which the two presidents ei2325:signed last May. In effect, the treaty amounts to Russian recognition of Ukraine's sovereignty and borders, and the Ukrainian parliament has already ei2326:ratified it. However, Russia has ei2327:stalled ei2328:ratification, ei2329:trying to ei2330:tie it to an agreement that would ei2332:permit the Russian navy to ei2333:use a naval base on Ukraine's Crimean peninsula for at least 20 more years. In their joint statement ei2334:issued after the ei2335:talks, Yeltsin and Kuchma ei2336:called for the fastest possible ei2337:ratification of the treaty, ei2338:saying it would ei2339:create a ``strong legal foundation'' for bilateral ties and ei2340:help stability in Europe. Kuchma ei2341:assured Yeltsin that Ukraine would not ei2342:join NATO, Yeltsin's spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky ei2343:said, ei2344:according to the Interfax news agency. The Russian leadership has staunchly ei2345:opposed the western alliance's ei2346:expansion into Eastern Europe. In their joint statement, ei2347:released by the Kremlin, the two leaders also ei2348:pledged to ei2349:consult each other regularly on their approaches to relations with NATO and, in particular, their action within the framework of NATO's Partnership for Peace program. Last year, Russian officials ei2350:assailed Ukraine for ei2351:holding joint naval ei2352:exercises with NATO in the Black Sea _ an area Moscow considers its own turf. Kuchma has ei2353:said repeatedly that Ukraine would ei2354:remain neutral for the foreseeable future. Yeltsin and Kuchma also ei2355:called for ei2356:developing the stagnant relations between the members of the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose coalition of former Soviet republics. In the past, Russia has often ei2357:claimed that Ukraine was ei2358:undermining efforts at closer cooperation within the CIS. A major goal of Kuchma's four-day state ei2359:visit was the ei2360:signing of a 10-year economic program ei2361:aimed at ei2362:doubling the two nations' trade turnover, which ei2363:fell to dlrs 14 billion last year, down dlrs 2.5 billion from 1996. The two presidents on Friday ei2364:signed the plan, which ei2365:calls for ei2366:cooperation in the metallurgy, fuel, energy, aircraft building, missile, space and chemical industries. A major project is joint ei2367:manufacturing of An-70 cargo planes, the Kremlin statement ei2368:said. The program also ei2369:calls for ei2370:coordination of economic reforms and joint ei2371:improvement of social programs in the two countries, where many people have become ei2372:impoverished during the chaotic post-Soviet ei2373:transition to capitalism. Kuchma also ei2374:planned to ei2375:visit Russian gas giant Gazprom, most likely to ei2376:discuss Ukraine's dlrs 1.2 billion debt to the company. (pvs/vi/ji)

text: MALAYSIA's aggressive ei243:move into the information age could not ei244:come in a more opportune time. With the ei245:convergence of communications and information technologies (IT) coupled with the ei246:coming of age for the Internet and its related technologies, the stage is ei247:set for Malaysians to ei248:seize the chance to ei249:transform into a knowledge society and ei250:become worthy opponents/players in the global market space. The Internet, the global network of computers, is now far ei252:reaching into the country - ei253:extending its embrace to ei254:include every nook and cranny of the nation - ei255:opening doors to not only a diverse range of information sources but also an exhaustive list of possibilities to ei256:create new applications which ei257:add value to people's lives. In the business world, the Internet - through intranet and extranet solutions - has ei258:become an invaluable tool for companies to harness so as to ei260:gain a competitive edge. The solutions are also vital components in ei261:developing the borderless marketing flagship application which is a vital element for ei262:spearheading the ei263:development of the Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC) project. The application will ei264:create the necessary framework and infrastructure to ei265:support electronic commerce (e-commerce) ei266:initiatives in the country. However, it is important to note that ei267:installing or ei268:implementing Internet technologies for technology's sake would not ei269:ensure instant ei270:success. For e-commerce to ei271:flourish with full-blown end-to-end business ei272:transactions, strategic ei273:planning which incorporates both business and technology plans that are complementary is necessary for an organisation to ei275:see feasible returns on investment. Intranets, through the use of Internet technology, are ei276:positioned as a platform for companies to ei277:optimise, ei278:expand and ei279:transform new channels of business. When strategically ei280:implemented, an intranet solution will ei281:provide the ability to ei282:mediate mission-critical, decision support functions in organisations. It will also ei283:help further ei284:improve communications and collaboration at all levels in an organisation. With intranets in place, it is only logical for organisations to respectively ei288:link the network to other companies' for extended business purposes through extranets. While this will ei289:enable the sharing of information among enterprises, security issues such as firewalls and encryption as well as access and control procedures, and the trust levels that enterprises have with each other will ei290:emerge and there will be a need to ei292:address them. Other than ei293:usage in business, Internet technology is also ei294:beginning to ei295:infiltrate the lifestyle domain. ``Smart homes'' have ei296:emerged ei297:bringing a wealth of information and entertainment to families over telecommunications lines. The art of socialising is also ei298:experiencing a ei299:change where Net/virtual relationships are fast ei300:overtaking or ei301:becoming parallel with the normal human relationships. Whether this would ei302:prove positive or otherwise towards society in the future is yet to be ei303:seen. All in all, the Internet ei304:has a lot to ei305:offer. However, its value and benefits are only as good as how we ei306:use it.

text:
International Women's Day is this coming Sunday, March eighth. A major focus of International Women's Day is the plight of Afghan women. Special ei430:events are being ei431:organized by the European Commission and individual nations in Europe, North America, and other parts of the world. Lisa Schlein reports from Geneva.
Afghanistan has been at war for twenty years, ei433:leaving a large part of the country's male population dead or in exile. The United Nations ei436:says women and children ei437:make up about seventy-five percent of the Afghan population. An Afghan refugee in Switzerland, Homira Atimadi, is a senior official of a group called the International Working Group on Afghan Women. The group has branches in Pakistan, Iran, Europe, Australia, and North America. Ms. Atimadi ei438:says Afghan women have been victims of severe ei440:violations of human rights for the past twenty years and she ei441:says she ei442:sees no ei443:end to the misery. She ei445:says security under the fundamentalist Taleban government is ei447:better, but everything else is ei448:worse.
Women do not ei449:become victims of armed ei451:attack, but they do not have the right to ei454:work. And today, the right to work is ei455:equal to r- the right to survival.
Ms. Atimadi ei456:says the ei457:war has ei458:created a nation of widows. Women have ei460:become the sole ei461:support of their families. Yet, the Taliban have ei462:forbidden them to ei463:work. She ei464:says this ei465:puts the very existence of women's families at risk. She ei467:says the plight of women in urban areas is ei469:greater than that which exists in rural parts of the country. In cities, such as the capital Kabul, women are totally ei470:dependent on international aid for survival. Ms. Atimadi ei472:says the women of Kabul ei473:symbolize the suffering of all the women in Afghanistan.
The aim is to ei475:bring in not only the focus on women's right to education, access to work, but ei476:look beyond that and ei477:look at the roots of, uh of these problems. These are only the symptoms of the problems that are ei478:facing Afghanistan. For women in Afghanistan to be ei490:able to ei480:realize their rights, there have to be conditions of peace and justice.
Ms. Atimadi ei482:says that is the primary focus of her group, peace and justice. She ei484:says her group is ei485:appealing to individuals, to the international community, and to the combatants and people of Afghanistan to ei486:stop the ei487:bloodletting which has ei488:torn the country apart. Lisa Schlein for VOA News, Geneva.

Control Data Corp., which just months ago was ei2637:hemorrhaging financially, ei2638:thinks it will be ei2748:healthy enough soon to ei2640:consider ei2641:repurchasing public debt.
Moreover, the company, whose go-it-alone approach nearly ei2642:proved fatal, now ei2643:sees alliances with others as the way back to prosperity in what it calls "the data solutions" business.
"I'm not saying everything is hunky-dory, but we have ei2645:completed the ei2646:transition," Robert M. Price, chairman and chief executive, ei2647:said in an ei2648:interview. "Transition" is a reference to the company's five-year restructuring ei2650:effort. During that time, Control Data ei2651:had losses of more than $1 billion.
Now, following asset sales that ei2653:shrank revenue by more than one-third this year alone, Control Data is ei2654:flush with cash. So its senior executives are ei2655:talking openly about possibly ei2656:buying back some of the company's $172.5 million in subordinated convertible debentures next year.
"We'd ei2657:like to ei2658:continue to ei2659:reduce debt," President Lawrence Perlman ei2660:said. ei2661:Noting that the company is ei2662:offering to ei2663:buy back $154.2 million in senior notes ei2664:paying 12 3/4%, he ei2665:said the response will ei2666:help ei2667:determine future debt-reduction ei2668:efforts. The ei2669:offer was automatically ei2670:triggered by the recent ei2671:sale of Control Data's Imprimis disk-drive business to Seagate Technology Inc.
Mr. Perlman, who is also acting chief financial officer and the odds-on favorite to become the next chief executive, ei2672:said the company is ei2673:achieving "modest positive cash ei2674:flow from operations, and we ei2676:expect that to ei2677:continue into 1990."
He ei2678:said the company ei2679:has no intention of ei2681:tapping its short-term bank lines "for a good part of 1990." Sometime next year, Control Data will " ei2682:develop a new bank relationship," Mr. Perlman ei2684:said. In recent months a group of lenders, led by Bank of America, has ei2685:extended Control Data up to $90 million in revolving loans through January, as well as $115 million in standby letters of credit.
Loan covenants require that the company achieve specified levels of operating earnings and meet a rolling four-quarter profitability test. Last week Control Data ei2686:reported third-quarter ei2687:earnings of $9.8 million, or 23 cents a share, on revenue of $763 million. Through the first nine months, the company ei2688:had a ei2689:loss of $484 million, largely reflecting the ei2690:closing of its supercomputer unit.
While a few assets are still being shopped -- including the sports and entertainment ticketing portion of the company's Ticketron unit -- Mr. Price ei2691:said future restructuring would be a question of strategy. "We don't ei2692:need the cash."
Ticketron's automated wagering business, which operates lotteries in a half dozen states, is not for sale, the company ei2695:said. Rather, Mr. Perlman ei2696:said, Control Data ei2697:intends to ei2698:bid for the coming Minnesota lottery contract and is ei2699:seeking new applications for the technology overseas, where "there is great interest in games of skill." He wouldn't ei2701:elaborate.
Control Data's semiconductor business, VTC Inc., ei2702:continues to ei2703:lose money, the executives ei2704:acknowledged, but they ei2705:said they consider some of the technology vital to national defense and so are ei2706:reluctant to ei2707:dispose of it.
The company's strategy for keeping its computer products business profitable -- it recently ei2708:achieved profitability after several quarters of ei2710:losses -- calls for a narrow focus and a lid on expenses. Partly, costs will be ei2711:held down through strategic technology alliances, management ei2712:said. Control Data recently ei2713:announced an ei2714:agreement with MIPS Computer Systems Inc. to jointly ei2715:develop machines with simplified operating software.
James E. Ousley, computer products group president, ei2716:said such arrangements could ei2718:help ei2719:slash Control Data's computer research and development costs in half by the end of 1990. He ei2720:disclosed that before Control Data ei2721:scrapped its ETA Systems Inc. supercomputer business this past spring, those costs were ei2722:running at nearly 35% of group revenue. At the same time four of six design projects were ei2723:spiked, he ei2724:said.
ei2725:Asked how the company ei2726:hopes to ei2727:expand its computer hardware business, Mr. Ousley ei2728:said it ei2729:sees good opportunities in systems integration. "We ei2730:think we're ei2731:getting only 10% of the integration dollars our customers are ei2732:spending," he ei2733:said. "We're in environments that are going to ei2734:spend a lot of money on that."
Control Data mainframes are designed for numerically intensive computing users, such as the scientific, engineering and academic communities. Utilities management is a major commercial niche.
ei2735:Reviewing the company's ei2736:scrape with disaster, Mr. Price ei2737:conceded it had ei2738:tried to ei2739:do too much on its own. "Absolutely," he said.
But while its stock is ei2740:selling at about half Control Data's estimated breakup value, neither Messrs. Perlman nor Price ei2741:said he ei2742:spends much time ei2743:considering the possibility of a hostile ei2744:takeover. "We've been ei2745:listed as a candidate for so long it's not worth worrying about," ei2747:said Mr. Price.

Polly Peck International Inc.'s ei1990:agreement to ei1991:acquire 51% of Sansui Electric Co. proves that foreign companies can acquire Japanese companies -- if the alternative for the Japanese company is extinction.
Polly Peck, a fast-growing British conglomerate, will ei1992:pay 15.6 billion yen ($110 million) for 39 million new shares of Sansui, a well-known maker of high-fidelity audio equipment that ei1993:failed to ei1994:adjust to changing market conditions. Japanese government officials, eager to ei1996:rebut foreign ei1997:criticism of Japanese ei1998:investments overseas, ei1999:hailed the ei2000:transaction as proof foreigners can make similar investments in Japan. Polly Peck's chairman, Asil Nadir, ei2001:echoed the official Japanese view of the ei2003:accord, which was ei2004:announced Friday.
"The myths that Japan is not open to concerns from outside has, I think, been ei2006:demolished at a stroke," Mr. Nadir ei2007:said.
But analysts ei2008:say Sansui is a special case. It ei2010:expects to ei2011:post a ei2012:loss of 6.4 billion yen for the year ending tomorrow and its liabilities currently ei2013:exceed its assets by about 13.8 billion yen. "If you ei2078:find sound, healthy companies in Japan, they are not for sale," ei2016:said George Watanabe, a management-consultant at Tokyo-based Asia Advisory Services Inc.
Statistics on acquisitions by foreigners vary in detail, because unlike Sansui, which is listed on the Tokyo and Osaka stock exchanges, most of the Japanese companies e3000:acquired by foreigners are privately held. But by all accounts foreign companies have bought only a relative handful of Japanese companies this year, while Japanese companies have acquired hundreds of foreign companies.
Nor do analysts ei2019:expect the Sansui deal to ei2020:touch off a fresh wave of foreign purchases. If the strong yen and the high stock prices of Japanese companies weren't deterrents enough, webs of cross-shareholdings between friendly Japanese companies and fiercely independent Japanese corporate attitudes ei2021:repel most would-be acquirers.
Usually when a Japanese company is ready to sell, it has few alternatives remaining, and the grim demeanors of Sansui's directors at a joint news conference here left little doubt that this was not the company's finest hour. Sansui was once one of Japan's premier makers of expensive, high-quality stereo gear for audiophiles.
But in recent years, the market has ei2022:moved toward less expensive "mini-component" sets, miniaturized amplifiers and receivers and software players that could be stacked on top of each other.
Some of Sansui's fellow audio-specialty companies, such as Aiwa Co. and Pioneer Electric Corp., ei2023:responded to the ei2024:challenge by quickly ei2025:bringing out mini-component products of their own, by ei2026:moving heavily into the booming compact disk businesses or by ei2027:diversifying into other consumer-electronics fields, including laser disks or portable cassette players. Sansui was late into the mini-component business and ei2028:failed to ei2029:branch into other new businesses.
As the yen ei2030:soared in recent years, Sansui's deepening financial problems ei2031:became a vicious circle. While competitors ei2033:moved production offshore in response to the sagging competitiveness of Japanese factories, Sansui ei2035:lacked the money to ei2036:build new plants in Southeast Asia. "Our company has not been ei2037:able to ei2038:cope very effectively with" ei2039:changes in the marketplace, ei2040:said Ryosuke Ito, Sansui's president.
But even a Japanese company that looks like a dog may turn out to be a good investment for a foreign concern, some management consultants maintain.
Yoshihisa Murasawa, a management consultant for Booz-Allen amp Hamilton (Japan) Inc., ei2041:said his firm will likely be ei2042:recommending ei2043:acquisitions of Japanese companies more often to foreign clients in the future. "Attitudes {toward being acquired} are still negative, but they're ei2044:becoming more positive," Mr. Murasawa ei2046:said. "In some industries, like pharmaceuticals, acquisitions ei2081:make sense."
Whether Polly Peck's ei2049:acquisition ei2080:makes sense ei2051:remains to be ei2052:seen, but at the news conference, Mr. Nadir ei2053:brimmed with self-confidence that he can ei2054:turn Sansui around. Sansui, he e3001:said, is a perfect fit for Polly Peck's electronics operations, which make televisions, videocassette recorders, microwaves and other products on an "original equipment maker" basis for sale under other companies' brand names.
He said Polly Peck will greatly ei2056:expand Sansui's product line, using Sansui's engineers to ei2058:design the new products, and will ei2059:move Sansui's production of most products other than sophisticated audio gear offshore into Polly Peck's own factories.
"Whatever capital it (Sansui) needs so it can ei2060:compete and ei2061:become a totally global entity capable of competing with the best in the world, that capital will be ei2062:injected," Mr. Nadir ei2063:said.
And while Polly Peck isn't ei2064:jettisoning the existent top-management structure of Sansui, it is ei2065:bringing in a former Toshiba Corp. executive as executive vice president and chief operating officer.
Such risk taking is an everyday matter for the brash Mr. Nadir, who is 25% owner of Polly Peck as well as its chairman. He ei2066:took Polly Peck, once a small fabric wholesaler, and ei2067:used it at as a base to ei2068:build a conglomerate that has been ei2069:doubling its profits annually since 1980. In September, it ei2070:announced ei2071:plans to ei2072:acquire the tropical-fruit business of RJR Nabisco Inc.'s Del Monte foods unit for #557 million ($878 million).
Last month, Polly Peck ei2073:posted a 38% ei2074:jump in pretax profit for the first half to #54.8 million from #39.8 million on a 63% ei2077:rise in sales.
Joann S. Lublin in London contributed to this article.

The bolstered cellular agreement between BellSouth Corp. and LIN Broadcasting Corp. carries heightened risks and could ei2575:fail to ei2576:fend off McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the rival suitor for LIN.
Moreover, the amended pact shows how McCaw's persistence has ei2578:pushed LIN and BellSouth into a corner, ei2579:forcing huge debt on the proposed new company. The debt, ei2580:estimated at $4.7 billion, could ei2582:mortgage the cellular company's future earning power in order to ei2583:placate some LIN holders in the short term.
The plan still ei2584:calls for LIN to ei2585:combine its cellular telephone properties with BellSouth's and to ei2586:spin off its broadcasting operations. "We're ei2605:taking on more debt than we would have ei2606:liked to," ei2607:acknowledged Michael Plouf, LIN's vice president and treasurer. Although he ei2608:expressed confidence that the proposed new company's cash flow would be ei2610:sufficient to ei2611:cover interest payments on the debt, he ei2612:estimated that the company wouldn't be ei2613:profitable until 1994 or later.
Analyst ei2614:estimate the value of the BellSouth proposal at about $115 to $125 a share. They ei2616:value McCaw's ei2617:bid at $112 to $118 a share. The previous BellSouth pact was ei2619:valued at about $98 to $110 a share.
McCaw, the largest provider of cellular telephone service in the U.S., already owns about 9.4% of LIN's stock. In response to BellSouth's amended pact, the Kirkland, Wash., company ei2621:extended its own ei2622:offer to ei2623:buy 22 million LIN shares for $125 apiece, which would ei2624:give McCaw a 50.3% controlling interest. Over the weekend, McCaw ei2625:continued to ei2626:call for an auction of LIN. Analysts ei2627:said they ei2628:expect McCaw to ei2629:escalate the bidding again.
"This game isn't over yet, " ei2631:said Joel D. Gross, a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin amp Jenrette Securities Corp. "At some point, it will ei2632:become non-economical for one company. But I don't ei2634:think we're at that point yet."
Under its revised ei2637:proposal, Atlanta-based BellSouth would ei2638:have a 50% interest in the new cellular company and would be ei2639:responsible for half of its debt. To ei2640:sweeten the pact further -- and to ei2641:ease concerns of institutional investors -- BellSouth ei2643:added a provision designed to ei2644:give extra protection to holders if the regional Bell company ever ei2646:decides to ei2647:buy the rest of the new cellular company. The provision, described as "back-end" protection, would ei2648:require BellSouth to ei2649:pay a price equivalent to what an outside party might have to pay.
McCaw's bid also has a similar clause. Only McCaw's proposal ei2650:requires the company to ei2651:begin an auction ei2652:process in June 1994 for remaining shares at third-party prices.
To ei2653:mollify shareholders ei2654:concerned about the long-term value of the company under the BellSouth-LIN agreement, BellSouth also ei2657:agreed to ei2658:pay as much as $10 a share, or $540 million, if, after five years, the trading value of the new cellular company isn't as high as the value that shareholders would have realized from the McCaw offer.
"We're very ei2660:pleased with the new deal. We didn't ei2662:expect BellSouth to be so ei2663:responsive," ei2664:said Frederick A. Moran, president of Moran Asset Management Inc., which holds 500,000 LIN shares. BellSouth's "back-end protection was flawed previously. We ei2665:think this is a superior deal to McCaw's. We're surprised. We didn't ei2667:think a sleeping {Bell} mentality would be ei2668:willing to ei2669:take on dilution."

text:
Market makers in Nasdaq over-the-counter stocks are ei1989:adding their voices to the swelling chorus of complaints about program trading.
Their motivation, however, has a strong practical aspect: Program trading is hazardous to their paychecks. The most controversial form of program trading, stock-index arbitrage, is " ei1991:making it tough for traders to make money," ei1992:declares Robert Antolini, head of OTC trading at Donaldson, Lufkin amp Jenrette.
Stock-index ei1993:arbitrage -- the computer-guided buying and selling of stocks with offsetting trades in stock-index futures to profit from fleeting price discrepancies -- ei1994:affects the OTC market directly through the 31 stocks included in Standard amp Poor's 500-stock index. The SampP 500 is often used in arbitrage strategies.
The portion of OTC volume attributable to program trading isn't known, as it is on the New York Stock Exchange, where it ei1996:amounted to more than 13% in September. ei1997:Estimates from traders put it at less than 5% of Nasdaq's average daily volume of roughly 133 million shares.
Other market-maker gripes: Program ei2000:trading also ei2001:causes the Nasdaq Composite Index to ei2002:lose ground against other segments of the stock market. Because of program ei2003:trading it is more ei2004:difficult to ei2005:trade many OTC stocks without sharp price ei2006:moves, a condition known as illiquidity. Moreover, the price ei2007:volatility that is ei2008:amplified by program ei2009:trading is ei2010:undercutting ei2011:efforts to ei2012:woo individual investors back to an OTC market that sorely ei2013:misses them.
Some of these ei2014:problems are neither new nor unique to the OTC market. But the big, often tumultuous ei2015:slide in stock prices this month has ei2016:turned some of those who have been ei2017:profiting from the practice against it.
Peter DaPuzzo, head of retail equity trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton, ei2019:acknowledges that he wasn't ei2020:troubled by program ei2021:trading when it ei2022:began in the pre-crash bull market because it ei2024:added liquidity and people were ei2025:pleased to ei2026:see stock prices ei2027:rising.
"We weren't as concerned until they ei2029:became sell programs," ei2030:says Mr. DaPuzzo, who now ei2031:thinks it ei2032:adds unnecessary volatility. Shearson Lehman, however, executes program trades for clients.
Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs and Kidder Peabody, in addition to Shearson, do program-trade OTC stocks. Shearson, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs say they do so only for customers, however. Kidder Peabody does program trading for its own as well as clients' accounts.
Of course, there were sell ei2033:programs in past years, too, but they ei2034:seem to ei2035:hurt market makers more painfully these days. That's largely because of defensive measures they ei2036:adopted after the 1987 ei2037:crash, when individual investors ei2038:fled the market and trading activity ei2039:dwindled. Market makers, to ei2040:cut costs, ei2041:slashed inventories of stocks they keep on hand to sell investors when other holders aren't selling.
And to ei2042:protect their reduced capital investment from ei2043:eroding further, market makers became quicker to ei2044:lower price quotes when sell programs are ei2138:in progress. On days when prices are tumbling, they must be ei2046:willing to ei2047:buy shares from sellers when no one else will. In such an environment, market makers can ei2048:suffer huge ei2049:losses both on trades made that day at steadily dropping prices and in the value of their inventories of shares.
"It ei2050:makes no ei2051:sense for us to ei2052:put money at risk when you ei2053:know you're going to lose," ei2055:says Mr. Antolini, of Donaldson Lufkin.
But this ei2056:skittishness, Mr. Antolini says, is ei2058:creating liquidity ei2059:problems in certain OTC stocks. "It's harder to sell stocks when the sell programs come in because some market makers don't want to { take the orders}. No one has big positions and no one wants to take big risks."
Joseph Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees trading on Nasdaq, ei2060:agrees that program trading is ei2061:hurting the market's ei2062:efforts to ei2063:bring back small investors. But, he ei2064:observes, while makers ei2065:suffer ei2066:losses when program trading ei2067:drags the market down, they also ei2068:make money when program trading ei2069:pushes the prices higher. "Sometimes {traders} ei2070:lose sight of that," he ei2071:says.
The OTC stocks in the SampP 500 include Nasdaq's biggest, such as Apple Computer, MCI Communications, Tele-Communications and Liz Claiborne. These big stocks greatly influence the Nasdaq Composite Index. When the computers say "sell," the composite tumbles as well as the Dow Jones Industrial Average.
The problem, market makers say, is that while the industrial average and the SampP 500 usually recover as buy programs kick in, the Nasdaq Composite frequently is left behind.
Eight trading days after Oct. 12, the day before the stock market ei2072:plunge, for instance, the Nasdaq Composite had ei2073:fallen 4.3%, compared with 3.3% for the SampP 500, 3.5% for the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index and 3.6% for the industrial average. This gap eventually ei2074:closes, but slowly. Three days later, as of Friday's ei2075:close, the Nasdaq Composite was down 6%, compared with 5.9% for the industrial average, 5.7% for the SampP 500 and 5.8% for the Big Board Composite.
The main reason for this ei2077:lag is that individual investors ei2078:own 65% of the OTC market's capitalization, ei2079:according to Mr. Hardiman, much more than on the Big Board. Such investors tend to be more cautious than institutional investors are about re-entering the market after massive selloffs, market makers say.
The Nasdaq Composite Index ei2080:tumbled 5.39, or 1.2% to 452.76 on Friday. For the week, the index ei2082:dropped 3.8%.
ei2083:Weakness in big technology stocks ei2084:hurt the composite as well as the Nasdaq 100 Index, which ei2085:fell 1.4%, or 6.43, on Friday, to 437.68. The Nasdaq Financial Index ei2087:lost about 1%, or 3.95, to 448.80.

London share prices ei1363:closed sharply lower Friday in active trading after Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson's ei1365:resignation ei1366:slapped the market and Wall Street's rapid initial sell-off ei1367:knocked it down.
London shares were ei1368:depressed initially by overnight ei1369:losses in New York and by the ei1370:drop in sterling after Mr. Lawson's ei1371:resignation. It showed some early resilience after central bank support ei1374:firmed sterling, but the weight of Wall Street late in London trading, and signs of further weakness in the British pound, proved a hefty load to ei1377:bear. New York stocks ei1378:recovered some of their losses after the London market ei1379:closed.
The Financial Times 100-share index ei1380:shed 47.3 points to ei1381:close at 2082.1, down 4.5% from the previous Friday and 6.8% from Oct. 13, when Wall Street's ei1382:plunge ei1383:helped ei1384:spark the current ei1385:weakness in London.
The 30-share index ei1386:settled 42.0 points lower at 1678.5. Volume was 840.8 million shares, up from 443.6 million Thursday and the week's most active session.
Dealers ei1391:said the turnover, largely confined to the 100-share index stocks, partly ei1392:reflected the ei1393:flurry of activity typical at the ei1394:close of a two-week trading account and the ei1396:start of a new account. But they ei1398:said Friday's focus on the top-tier stocks ei1399:telegraphed active overseas ei1400:selling and ei1401:showed the broad-based fears over the status of the U.K. economy and Britain's currency in the wake of the ei1404:upheaval in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's cabinet.
A senior dealer with Warburg Securities ei1405:noted British Gas, the most active blue-chip stock at 20 million shares traded, was ei1406:affected by the political implications of Mr. Lawson's ei1407:departure and Mrs. Thatcher's cabinet ei1408:shuffle.
He ei1409:attributed the unusually high volume to broad-based ei1411:selling on fears that the Thatcher government may be ei1528:in turmoil and Britain's Labor Party ei1414:positioned to ei1415:regain control of the government and ei1417:renew ei1418:efforts at ei1419:nationalization.
British Gas ei1420:shed 8.5 pence a share to ei1421:close at 185 pence ($2.90).
Other dealers ei1423:added that the blue-chip stocks in general were ei1424:hit by profit-taking over concerns that London shares will ei1426:continue ei1427:posting ei1428:declines and the uncertainty over sterling given that Mr. Lawson's successor, John Major, had only been in the job one day.
Besides British Gas, British Steel ei1431:skidded 1.74 to 123.5 on turnover of 11 million shares.
British Petroleum ei1433:fell 5 to 286 on 14 million shares traded. Dealers ei1435:said the multinational oil company was ei1436:pressured by recent brokerage recommendations ei1437:urging investors to ei1438:switch into Shell Trading amp Transport. Shell ei1439:eased 1 to 416 on turnover of 4.8 million shares.
Among the other actively traded blue-chip issues, Imperial Chemical Industries ei1441:dropped 11 to #10.86, Hanson ei1443:skidded 9.5 to 200.5, and British Telecom ei1445:fell 10 to 250.
In Tokyo, stocks ei1447:closed lower but above intraday lows in active trading. The Nikkei index was ei1449:pressured down by ei1451:profit-taking ei1452:triggered by sharp ei1453:advances made through this week and ei1454:fell 151.20 points to 35527.29.
In early ei1456:trading in Tokyo Monday, the Nikkei index ei1457:fell 148.85 points to 35378.44.
On Friday, the Tokyo stock price index of first section issues was down 15.82 at 2681.76. First-section volume was ei1460:estimated at 1.3 billion shares, up from 886 million shares Thursday.
An official at Wako Securities ei1463:said brokerages' excessive expectations about recent ei1465:advances in Tokyu Group shares and real estate issues were ei1466:dashed Friday.
Dealers ei1467:placed heavy buy orders in the morning to ei1469:start the first trading day for November ei1471:transactions. But they ei1472:failed to ei1473:sell these stocks to client investors, who were ei1474:cautious about the sharp ei1475:gains these issues ei1476:made this week, the Wako official ei1477:said.
Fund managers ei1478:said Friday's ei1479:profittaking was a natural ei1480:result of the week's "abnormal fever" in ei1482:buying real estate, shipbuilding, steel and construction shares.
Frankfurt prices ei1483:closed lower again Friday, the fourth ei1485:decline in the past five days and the ei1486:culmination of a week that saw the DAX index ei1487:lose 4%. The DAX ei1488:dropped 19.69 points Friday to 1462.93.
Traders ei1490:said the continued ei1491:turbulence in other markets, coupled with the ei1492:drop in London following the Lawson ei1493:resignation, were ei1494:responsible.
Traders ei1495:said that selling pressure wasn't enormous and that the DAX ei1496:dropped Friday more on a lack of any substantial buying interest. They ei1498:said contributing to the downward ei1499:drift was the fact that many professional traders had ei1500:chosen to ei1501:square positions ahead of the weekend.
"It's the whole uncertainty about what's happening around us," e130:said Valentin Von Korff, a trader at Credit Suisse First Boston in Frankfurt.
"If you e131:take away the outside influences, the market itself looks very cheap. What's happening here isn't justified by the fundamentals."
Traders said the market remains extremely nervous because of the wild swings seen on the New York Stock Exchange last week. That's leaving small investors with cold feet, they said, and prompting institutions to take a reserved stance on the sidelines as well, at least until the market in New York ei1510:settles down somewhat.
Elsewhere, share prices ei1511:closed lower in Paris, Zurich, Amsterdam, Brussels and Stockholm, and were ei1513:mixed in Milan. The British ei1514:shakeup was widely ei1515:cited for the ei1516:declines.
Share prices also ei1517:closed lower in Sydney, Hong Kong, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Wellington and Seoul. Concern about ei1520:declines in other markets, especially New York, ei1521:caused selling ei1523:pressure.
Here are price trends on the world's major stock markets, as ei1524:calculated by Morgan Stanley Capital International Perspective, Geneva. To make them directly comparable, each index is based on the close of 1969 equaling 100. The percentage ei1525:change is since year-end.

This hasn't been Kellogg Co.'s year. The oat-bran ei1994:craze has ei1995:cost the world's largest cereal maker market share. The company's president ei1996:quit suddenly. And now Kellogg is indefinitely ei1997:suspending ei1998:work on what was to be a $1 billion cereal plant.
The company ei2000:said it was ei2001:delaying ei2002:construction because of current market ei2003:conditions. But the Memphis, Tenn., facility wasn't to ei2004:begin ei2005:turning out product until 1993, so the ei2006:decision may reveal a more pessimistic long-term outlook as well.
Kellogg, which hasn't been as ei2008:successful in ei2009:capitalizing on the public's health-oriented desire for oat bran as rival General Mills Inc., has been ei2010:losing share in the $6 billion ready-to-eat cereal market. Kellogg's current share is ei2011:believed to be slightly under 40% while General Mills' share is about 27%.
ei2014:Led by its oat-based Cheerios line, General Mills has ei2015:gained an estimated 2% share so far this year, mostly at the expense of Kellogg. Each share point is worth about $60 million in sales.
Analysts ei2017:say much of Kellogg's ei2018:erosion has been in such core brands as Corn Flakes, Rice Krispies and Frosted Flakes, which represent nearly one-third of its sales volume. Kellogg is so ei2019:anxious to ei2020:turn around Corn Flakes sales that it soon will ei2021:begin ei2022:selling boxes for as little as 99 cents, trade sources ei2023:say.
"Cheerios and Honey Nut Cheerios have ei2024:eaten away sales normally ei2025:going to Kellogg's corn-based lines simply because they are ei2026:made of oats," ei2027:says Merrill Lynch food analyst William Maguire. "They are not a ei2127:happy group of people at Battle Creek right now." Kellogg is based in Battle Creek, Mich., a city that calls itself the breakfast capital of the world.
Another analyst, John C. Maxwell Jr. of Wheat, First Securities in Richmond, Va., recently ei2137:went to a "sell" recommendation on Kellogg stock, which ei2031:closed Friday at $71.75, down 75 cents, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. "I don't ei2034:think Kellogg can ei2035:get back to 40% this year," he ei2037:said. "Kellogg's main problem is life style. People are ei2038:reading the boxes and ei2039:deciding they ei2040:want something that's `healthy' for you -- oats, bran." Mr. Maxwell ei2042:said he wouldn't be ei2043:surprised if, over the next two years or so, General Mills' share ei2044:increased to 30% or more.
In ei2045:announcing the plant ei2046:delay, Kellogg Chairman William E. LaMothe ei2047:said, "Cereal volume ei2048:growth in the U.S. has not ei2049:met our ei2050:expectations for 1989". He ei2051:said ei2052:construction wouldn't ei2053:resume until market conditions ei2054:warrant it.
Kellogg ei2055:indicated that it ei2056:has room to ei2057:grow without ei2058:adding facilities. The company ei2059:has five other U.S. plants, including a modern facility at its Battle Creek headquarters known as Building 100, which is to ei2060:add bran-processing and rice-processing capacity next year.
General Mills, meanwhile, finds itself ei2062:constrained from ei2063:boosting sales further because its plants are ei2064:operating at capacity. A large plant in Covington, Ga., is to ei2065:come on line next year.
A Kellogg officer, who asked not to be named, ei2066:said the Memphis project was " ei2067:pulled in for a ei2068:reconsideration of costs," an indication that the ambitious plans might be ei2069:scaled back in any future ei2070:construction. Initial cost estimates for the plant, which was to have been built in phases, ei2071:ranged from $1 billion to $1.2 billion.
A company spokesman ei2072:said it was "possible, but highly unlikely," that the plant might never be ei2073:built. "As we ei2074:regain our leadership level where we have been, and as we ei2076:continue to ei2077:put new products into the marketplace and ei2078:need additional capacity, we will ei2080:look at ei2081:resuming our ei2082:involvement with our plan," he ei2083:said.
The new facility was to have been the world's most advanced cereal manufacturing plant, and Kellogg's largest construction project. The company had ei2086:retained the Fluor Daniel unit of Fluor Corp. as general contractor.
But in recent weeks, construction-industry sources ei2087:reported that early preparation work was ei2088:slowing at the 185-acre site. Subcontractors ei2089:said they were ei2090:told that equipment ei2091:orders would be ei2092:delayed. Fluor Daniel already has ei2093:reassigned most of its work crew, the sources ei2094:said.
Last Friday's ei2095:announcement was the first official word that the project was ei2129:in trouble and that the company's plans for a surge in market share may have been overly ei2130:optimistic. Until recently, Kellogg had been ei2098:telling its sales force and Wall Street that by 1992 it ei2099:intended to ei2100:achieve a 50% share of market, measured in dollar volume.
Although he ei2102:called current market conditions "highly competitive," Mr. LaMothe, Kellogg's chairman and chief executive officer, ei2104:forecast an earnings ei2105:increase for the full year. Last year, the company ei2106:earned $480.4 million, or $3.90 a share, on sales of $4.3 billion.
As ei2107:expected, Kellogg ei2108:reported lower third-quarter earnings. Net ei2110:fell 16% to $123.1 million, or $1.02 a share, from $145.7 million, or $1.18 a share. Sales ei2113:rose 4.8% to $1.20 billion from $1.14 billion.
The company ei2116:had a one-time ei2117:charge of $14.8 million in the latest quarter covering the ei2118:disposition of certain assets. The company wouldn't ei2119:elaborate, ei2120:citing competitive reasons.

General Motors Corp. ei2451:wants to ei2452:buy as much as 15% of Jaguar PLC, ei2453:marking its first salvo in a possible full-scale ei2455:battle against Ford Motor Co. for ei2456:control of the British car maker.
GM ei2457:sought U.S. antitrust ei2458:clearance last week to ei2459:purchase more than $15 million worth of Jaguar shares but doesn't ei2460:own any yet, ei2461:according to GM officials here and at the company's Detroit headquarters. The No. 1 U.S. auto maker then ei2462:wrote Jaguar that it ei2463:intends "to ei2464:go to that 15%" level once it ei2466:wins the U.S. ei2467:clearance to ei2468:go beyond $15 million, a Jaguar spokesman ei2470:said yesterday.
The GM ei2471:move follows Tuesday's ei2472:declaration by Ford, which holds an unwelcome 12.45% stake in Jaguar, that it is ei2473:prepared to ei2474:bid for the entire company. GM is close to ei2475:completing a friendly ei2476:deal with Jaguar that is likely to ei2477:involve an eventual 30% stake and joint manufacturing ventures. Speculative investors, ei2479:betting on an imminent ei2480:clash between Ford and GM, ei2481:pushed up Jaguar's share price five pence (eight U.S. cents) to a near-record 720 pence ($11.60) in late ei2484:trading on London's stock exchange yesterday. Since Tuesday, the shares have ei2485:gained nearly 4%.
But an all-out bidding ei2486:war between the world's top auto giants for Britain's leading luxury-car maker seems unlikely. "We will not ei2487:go over a certain level," ei2488:said David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, at a news ei2489:conference yesterday in Dearborn, Mich. "There's some price at which we'd ei2490:stop ei2491:bidding." He wouldn't ei2492:specify what it was.
And powerful political ei2493:pressures may ei2494:convince the Conservative government to ei2495:keep its so-called golden share, which limits any individual holding to 15%, until the restriction ei2497:expires on Dec. 31, 1990.
"I really don't ei2498:see the government ei2499:doing something that Jaguar doesn't ei2500:want over the next 14 months," ei2501:said Kenneth Warren, a Conservative member of Parliament and chairman of the Select Committee on Trade and Industry in Britain's House of Commons. "The golden share is a single share, but it is the magic share."
The government ei2502:retained the single share after ei2503:selling its stake in Jaguar in 1984 -- part of a nationalistic practice of protecting former government-owned enterprises to deflect criticism of privatization. The 15% restriction covers any would-be suitor, British or foreign.
Ford is ei2504:willing to ei2505:bid for 100% of Jaguar's shares if both the government and Jaguar shareholders ei2506:agree to ei2507:relax the anti-takeover barrier prematurely. As Jaguar's biggest holder and Britain's biggest car maker, Ford could ei2508:turn up the heat by ei2509:convening a special shareholders' ei2510:meeting and ei2511:urging holders to ei2512:drop the limits early. Ford might ei2513:succeed because many shareholders are speculators ei2514:keen for a full ei2515:bid or institutional investors ei2516:unhappy over Jaguar management's ei2517:handling of its current financial ei2518:difficulties.
The government probably wouldn't ei2519:give in readily to a hostile foray by Ford, however. It has ei2520:relinquished a golden share only once before -- during British Petroleum Co.'s #2.5 billion ( $4 billion ) ei2521:takeover of Britoil PLC in 1988.
In ei2522:wooing British lawmakers, GM has ei2523:pointed out that its willingness to ei2525:settle for a minority stake would ei2526:keep Jaguar ei2527:British-owned and ei2528:independent. This week, the U.S. auto giant ei2529:paid for 10 House of Commons members and two House of Lords members to ei2530:fly to Detroit and ei2531:tour its operations there. While the ei2532:visit was unrelated to Jaguar, GM Chairman Roger Smith ei2533:answered the legislators' ei2534:questions about it over ei2535:lunch Tuesday. He ei2536:said Jaguar "shouldn't be ei2537:smothered by anyone else, " ei2538:recalled one participant.
Politics also influences the government's thinking on the anti-takeover restriction. The Conservatives don't dare jeopardize marginal Tory seats in Coventry, where Jaguar has headquarters, nor can the government easily back down on promised protection for a privatized company while it proceeds with controversial plans to privatize most of Britain's water and electricity industries.

Billions of investors' dollars are ei2578:pouring out of the nation's junk-bond mutual funds, ei2579:undermining a pillar of support in the already reeling junk market.
Last week alone, an eye-popping $1.6 billion ei2580:flowed out of the junk funds, or nearly 5% of their total assets, ei2581:according to estimates by Dalbar Financial Services Inc., a Boston research firm.
In the past two months the nation's 88 junk funds have ei2582:lost a total of about $6 billion -- more than 15% of assets -- through ei2583:sales or ei2584:transfers of junk-fund shares, Dalbar ei2585:says. It made the estimates based on data collected from more than a dozen big junk funds.
ei2586:Interviews with three major fund groups -- Fidelity Investments, Vanguard Group Inc. and T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. -- ei2587:confirm the ei2588:trend. Their junk funds combined have had net ei2589:outflows totaling nearly $500 million, or about 13% of their junk fund assets, in the past two months.
Some fund managers ei2590:say negative publicity has ei2591:exacerbated investors' concern about recent ei2592:declines in junk-bond prices. "People have been seeing headline after headline after headline and saying: `I can't take it anymore -- I'm getting out,'" ei2593:says Kurt Brouwer of Brouwer amp Janachowski, a San Francisco investment adviser.
The ei2594:withdrawals could ei2595:spell trouble for the $200 billion junk market. If the heavy ei2597:outflows ei2598:continue, fund managers will ei2599:face increasing ei2600:pressure to ei2601:sell off some of their junk to ei2602:pay departing investors in the weeks ahead. Such ei2603:selling could ei2604:erode prices of high-yield junk bonds, already ei2605:weakened by a rash of corporate credit problems.
Mutual fund groups haven't ei2607:lost control of much of the outgoing money, ei2608:says Louis Harvey, Dalbar's president. Mutual fund officials ei2609:say that investors have ei2610:transferred most of it into their money market accounts, and to a lesser extent, government-bond funds. So the ei2611:impact on the $950 billion mutual fund industry as a whole probably will be slight.
But tremors are likely in the junk-bond market, which has ei2612:helped to ei2613:finance the takeover ei2614:boom of recent years. Mutual funds are the among the largest holders of junk, accounting for more than a quarter of the entire high-yield, high-risk market. The 88 mutual funds investing solely in junk bonds hold assets of about $32 billion. Other funds hold a smattering of junk bonds, too.
The $1.5 billion Fidelity High Income Fund has had a net ei2615:outflow of about $150 million in the past two months. About $60 million ei2616:streamed out last week alone, double the level of the week following last month's Campeau Corp. credit ei2619:squeeze. About 98% of the outflow was ei2620:transferred to other Fidelity funds, ei2621:says Neal Litvack, a Fidelity vice president, marketing, with most ei2622:going into money market funds.
"You get a news item, it hits, you have strong e3000:redemptions that day and for two days following -- then go back to normal," ei2623:says Mr. Litvack. The fund, with a cash cushion of more than 10%, has " met all the redemptions without having to sell one thing," Mr. Litvack says. He ei2627:adds: "Our fund has had {positive} net ei2628:sales every month for the last three years -- until this month."
Vanguard's $1 billion High Yield Bond Portfolio has ei2629:seen $161 million ei2630:flow out since early September; $14 million of that ei2631:seeped out Friday Oct. 13 alone. Still, two-thirds of the ei2632:outflow has been ei2633:steered into other Vanguard portfolios, ei2634:says Brian Mattes, a vice president. The fund now ei2635:holds a cash position of about 15%.
At the $932 million T. Rowe Price High Yield Fund, investors ei2636:yanked out about $182 million in the past two months. Those ei2637:withdrawals, most of which were ei2638:transferred to other T. Rowe Price funds, followed little ei2639:change in the fund's sales picture this year through August. "The last two months have been the whole ball ei2640:game," ei2641:says Steven Norwitz, a vice president.
Junk-fund holders have barely ei2642:broken even this year, as fat interest payments barely ei2643:managed to offset declining prices. Through Oct. 19, high-yield funds ei2644:had an average 0.85% total return (the price change plus dividends on fund shares), ei2645:according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc. That's even less than the 4.35% total return of the Merrill Lynch High-Yield Index.
Fidelity's junk fund has ei2646:fallen 2.08% this year through Oct. 19, Lipper ei2647:says; the Vanguard fund ei2648:rose 1.84%; and the T. Rowe Price fund ei2649:edged up 0.66%.
People who ei2650:remain in junk funds now could ei2651:get ei2652:hit again, some analysts and fund specialists ei2653:say. Many funds in recent weeks and months have been ei2654:selling their highest-quality junk issues, such as RJR Nabisco, to ei2655:raise cash to ei2657:meet expected ei2659:redemptions.
Funds might be ei2660:forced to ei2661:accept lower prices if they ei2663:expand their ei2664:selling to the securities of less-creditworthy borrowers. And then, asset values of the funds could ei2665:plunge more than they have so far.
Says Michael Hirsch, chief investment officer of Republic National Bank and manager of the FundTrust Group in New York: "It's a time bomb just waiting to go off."

The government is ei1988:sharpening its newest weapon against white-collar defendants: the power to ei1990:prevent them from ei1991:paying their legal bills. And defense lawyers are ei1992:warning that they won't ei1993:stick around if they don't get ei1994:paid.
The issue has come to a boil in Newark, N.J., where federal prosecutors have ei1995:warned lawyers for Eddie Antar that if the founder and former chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc. is ei1996:indicted, the government may ei1997:move to ei1998:seize the money that Mr. Antar is ei1999:using to ei2000:pay legal fees.

In those cases, the high court ei2003:ruled that federal law ei2004:gives prosecutors broad authority to ei2006:seize assets of people accused of racketeering and drug-related crimes, including fees paid to lawyers before an indictment.

A ei2012:seizure also would ei2013:make the case the largest -- and one of the first -- in which lawyers' fees have been confiscated in a prosecution unrelated to drugs.

Mr. Antar is being ei2020:investigated by a federal grand jury in Newark, where prosecutors have ei2021:told him that they may soon ei2022:seek an indictment on racketeering and securities fraud charges. In a letter, prosecutors ei2034:told Mr. Antar's lawyers that because of the recent Supreme Court ei2035:rulings, they could ei2036:expect that any fees collected from Mr. Antar may be ei2037:seized. Prosecutors have ei2038:told Mr. Antar's attorneys that they ei2039:believe Mr. Antar's allegedly ill-gotten gains are so great that any money he has used to pay attorneys ei2040:derives from illegal ei2041:activities. Therefore, they ei2042:said, the money can be ei2043:taken from the lawyers even after they are ei2044:paid.
Justin Feldman and Jack Arseneault, attorneys for Mr. Antar, both ei2045:declined to ei2046:comment on the matter.

Mr. Antar, the SEC ei2077:said, ei2078:made more than $60 million from the ei2079:sale of his shares between 1985 and 1987.
The Justice Department has ei2080:emphasized that the government's fee-forfeiture power is to be ei2081:used sparingly. ei2082:According to department policy, prosecutors must make a strong ei2083:showing that lawyers' fees ei2084:came from assets tainted by illegal profits before any ei2085:attempts at ei2086:seizure are ei2087:made.

Intel Corp.'s most powerful computer chip ei2216:has flaws that could ei2217:delay several computer makers' marketing ei2218:efforts, but the "bugs" aren't ei2219:expected to ei2220:hurt Intel and most computer makers.
Computer experts familiar with the flaws, found in Intel's 80486 chip, ei2221:say the defects don't ei2222:affect the average user and are likely to be ei2223:cleared up before most computers using the chip as their " brains " ei2224:appear on the market sometime next year.
Intel ei2225:said that last week a customer ei2226:discovered two flaws in its 80486 microprocessor chip's "floating-point unit", a set of circuits that do certain calculations. On Friday, Intel ei2228:began ei2229:notifying customers about the bugs which ei2231:cause the chip to ei2232:give wrong answers for some mathematical calculations.
But while International Business Machines Corp. and Compaq Computer Corp. ei2234:say the bugs will ei2235:delay products, most big computer makers ei2237:said the flaws don't ei2238:affect them. "Bugs like this are just a normal part of product development," ei2240:said Richard Archuleta, director of Hewlett-Packard Co.'s advanced systems development. Hewlett ei2241:announced last week that it ei2242:planned to ei2243:ship a computer based on the 486 chip early next year. "These bugs don't ei2244:affect our schedule at all," he ei2245:said.
Likewise, AST Research Inc. and Sun Microsystems Inc. ei2246:said the bugs won't ei2247:delay their ei2248:development of 486-based machines. "We haven't ei2249:modified our schedules in any way," ei2250:said a Sun spokesman. To ei2251:switch to another vendor's chips, "would not definitely be an option," he ei2253:said.
Nonetheless, concern about the chip may have been responsible for a ei2256:decline of 87.5 cents in Intel's stock to $32 a share yesterday in over-the-counter ei2258:trading, on volume of 3,609,800 shares, and partly responsible for a ei2260:drop in Compaq's stock in New York Stock Exchange composite ei2261:trading on Wednesday. Yesterday, Compaq ei2262:plunged further, ei2263:closing at $100 a share, off $8.625 a share, on volume of 2,633,700 shares.
Most of Compaq's ei2265:decline is being ei2266:attributed to a third-quarter earnings report that came in at the low end of analysts' expectations.
Intel ei2268:said it had ei2269:corrected the problems and would ei2271:start ei2272:producing bugless chips next week. "We should not be ei2273:seeing any more," ei2274:said Bill Rash, Intel's director for the 486 chip.
What's more, the bugs only ei2275:emerge on esoteric applications such as computer-aided design and scientific calculations, he ei2276:said, and then very seldom. "These errata do not ei2277:affect business programs," he ei2278:said. The bugs will ei2279:cause problems in "specific and rare circumstances that will not occur in typical applications" such as word-processing and spreadsheets, ei2281:said Michael Slater, editor of the Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter.
Sun, Hewlett-Packard and others ei2282:say Intel isn't wholly to blame for the snafu. The real culprits, they ei2283:said, are computer makers such as IBM that have ei2284:jumped the gun to ei2285:unveil 486-based products. "The reason this is getting so much visibility is that some ei2286:started ei2287:shipping and ei2288:announced early availability," ei2290:said Hewlett-Packard's Mr. Archuleta. "You can do that but you're taking a risk. Those companies are paying the price for taking the risk."
In late September, IBM ei2291:began ei2292:shipping a plug-in card that converts its PS/2 model 70-A21 from a 80386 machine to an 80486 machine. An IBM spokeswoman ei2293:said the company ei2294:told customers Monday about the bugs and temporarily ei2296:stopped ei2297:shipping the product.
IBM ei2298:has no plans to ei2299:recall its add-on cards, the spokeswoman ei2300:said, and could probably ei2301:circumvent the bugs without long product ei2302:delays. "We don't ei2303:look at this as a major problem for us," she ei2304:said.
Compaq, which ei2305:said it ei2306:discovered the bugs, still ei2307:plans to ei2308:announce new 486 products on Nov. 6. Because of the glitch, however, the company ei2310:said it doesn't ei2311:know when its machine will be commercially ei2312:available. That's a break from Compaq tradition, because the company doesn't announce products until they're actually at the dealers.
The problem is being ei2313:ballyhooed, experts ei2314:say, because the 486 is Intel's future flagship. Intel's microprocessors are the chips of choice in many of today's personal computers and the 80486 microprocessor is the spearhead of the company's bid to guard that spot in the next generation of machines.
"Although these sorts of bugs are not at all uncommon, the 486 is an extremely high-profile product," ei2316:said Mr. Slater, the newsletter editor.
Intel's 80486 chip is the Corvette of Intel's microprocessors, a super-fast, super-expensive chip that only the most power-hungry computer users are likely to buy for at least several years.
Unveiled last April, the chip crams 1.2 million transistors on a sliver of silicon, more than four times as many as on Intel's earlier model, 80386. Intel clocks the chip's speed at 15 million instructions per second, or MIPs. That's four times as fast as the 386.
Machines ei2318:using the 486 are ei2319:expected to ei2320:challenge higher-priced work stations and minicomputers in applications such as so-called servers, which connect groups of computers together, and in computer-aided design.
But while the chip's speed in processing power is dazzling, it's real strength lies in its software inheritance. The 486 is the descendant of a long series of Intel chips that ei2321:began ei2322:dominating the market ever since IBM ei2323:picked the 16-bit 8088 chip for its first personal computer. (A 16-bit microprocessor processes 16 pieces of data at a time and is slower than newer, 32-bit chips.) Since then, Intel has ei2324:cornered a large part of the market with successive generations of 16-bit and 32-bit chips, all of which can run software written for previous models.
That's what will ei2325:keep computer makers ei2326:coming in spite of the irritation of bugs. Big personal computer makers and many makers of engineering workstations are ei2327:developing 486-based machines, which are ei2328:expected to ei2329:reach the market early next year.
Of the big computer makers, only Apple Computer Co. bases its machines on Motorola chips instead. "The 486 is going to ei2330:have a big ei2331:impact on the industry," ei2332:said Hewlett-Packard's Mr. Archuleta. "It's going to be the leading edge technology in personal computers for the next few years. This bug is not going to ei2334:have any affect on that at all."
Andy Zipser in Dallas contributed to this article.
